results.title: Waterworld
results.brief_description: In a futuristic world where the polar ice caps have melted and made Earth a liquid planet, a beautiful barmaid rescues a mutant seafarer from a floating island prison.

constellations_other.name: Cartoon classics and criticism
constellations_other.description: A whole cavalcade of cartoons have successfully made the leap into arcades and onto consoles, but the relationship between cinema and videogames is far more likely to fizzle out.

results.description: In a futuristic world where the polar ice caps have melted and made Earth a liquid planet, a beautiful barmaid rescues a mutant seafarer from a floating island prison. They escape, along with her young charge, Enola, and sail off aboard his ship.

results.title: Waterworld
results.brief_description: A ridiculed adaptation of the Kevin Costner vehicle Waterworld, which translated the Mad Max narrative from the desert to the sea.

constellations_other.name: Cartoon classics and criticism

results.description: The sun. For millions of years the source of life. But for one planet the source of it’s demise. The temperature climbed, the vast pools of ice at it’s poles melted, and the oceans rose. Centuries later, few people remained on this planet, once called Earth. A lone mariner sails the expanse of water, trading to survive. For survival, is all these people do, in this place they know only as Waterworld.

results.title: Waterworks
results.brief_description: ‘Waterworks’ is an in depth series produced by the ABC on water and covers areas such as; human usage, molecular properties and the role of water in the ecology.

results.title: Watership down
results.brief_description:
One dim moonlit night, a small band of rabbits leave the comfort and safety of their warren and set out on a long and dangerous journey after a premonition of a terrible disaster that will overtake them if they stay. None of them knows where they are heading, or the dangers they will face in their search for a new warren where they can live in peace. Adapted from Richard Adams’ modern classic.
Voiced by actors including: John Hurt, Richard Briers, Ralph Richardson, Denholm Elliott, Zero Mostel, Nigel Hawthorne, Michael Hordern, Joss Ackland.

results.title: Waters of time
results.brief_description: Produced for the Festival of Britain, this film combines a series of impressions of life along the 69 miles of the Thames from the mouth of the river to Kingston. The camera explores the wharves and warehouses of the waterfront; the docking of a ship; loading and reloading of its cargo; aerial views of the port; busy activity in the holds of the ships; wine cellars in warehouse basements. In the factual passages of the film the commentary is spoken by a dockmaster and docker; in the remainder of the film, the commentary is in prose and verse.

results.title: Waters of life
results.creator_credit: Central Office of Information and Greenpark Productions
results.brief_description: The advantages of the Colombo Plan to the people of Ceylon. Shows how the old way of living, with its drought, disease and lack of agriculture has been changed by the new schemes providing for controlled irrigation, clearing of land, and resettling of villages. Adapted from the Ceylon Government Film “New Horizons”.

results.title: Waterloo farmers
results.creator_credit: Italo Costa, Gary Toole, Roman Bittman and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film juxtaposes Old Order Mennonites and New Order Mennonites. Their differing beliefs are reflected in their methods of farming. One has not changed in four hundred years; the other is up-to-date and mechanized. The film asks whether a compromise will eventually have to be reached between the two.

results.title: Waterloo bridge
results.creator_credit: Mervyn LeRoy, Sidney A. Franklin and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Starring Vivian Leigh and Robert Taylor, this is a tragic tale. An army officer marries a ballerina. When he is reported missing his family ignores her and she sinks into prostitution. A ‘weepie’ which has had mixed reviews over time, but still remains very popular.

results.title: Waterloo
results.creator_credit: Tom Zubrycki and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Set in Waterloo, an inner city suburb of Sydney, this film describes the bitter and drawn out struggle of a group of residents to save their suburb from slum clearance and redevelopment by state housing authorities. Making extensive use of newsreels, stills and re-enactment, “Waterloo” examines the struggle in the context of the history of Sydney’s inner city suburbs from the anti eviction campaigns of the 1930s to the rise of the resident action movement of the late 1960s. This film shows how squatting and trade union intervention eventually succeeded in forcing the government to recognise the right of the ordinary people to participate in planning decisions affecting the future of their communities. Four months after this film was first publicly screened in 1981, the residents of Waterloo won their battle. The film played a major part in that victory.

results.title: Waterloo
results.creator_credit: C. de Renesse, E. Bernhard and Filmsonor
results.brief_description: Wellington’s headquarters still stand in the peaceful village of Waterloo; Napoleon’s army tent, swords are on display in the museum where visitors are shepherded past wax figures, paintings, firearms, and even skeletons collected from the battlefields. The camera takes in the silent brooding landscape, then turns to the painted war scenes to recreate the battle.
